Map: ^You open your map. Where would you like to go?
Downtown: ^Some kids stand along the sidewalk. Not much to do here right now.
Playground: ^It's a playground. Not much to do here right now.

Day1: ^Your mom is standing in front of the house. Not much to do here right now.
Intro: ^Your mom is standing on the porch.
Mom1: ^Dana: Mom! Look! God sent me a baby!
^It seems that Kimmy has something to say.

g-0: ^Mom: That… No, Dana. God did not send you a baby.
^Dana: What do you mean…? You said God sends people babies sometimes! You told me that.
^Mom: Well… nevermind what I said. It doesn’t apply to you. God isn’t about to send you a baby anytime soon, trust me.
^Dana: What! Why? I wished for a baby, and he granted my wish. Isn’t it obvious?
^Mom: Where did you find this little girl? Honey, where’s your house?
^It seems that Kimmy has something to say.
g-1: ^Mom: Kimmy, can you tell me where your parents are?
^Kimmy: I can go home later if I want…
^Dana: Well maybe God didn’t send her, but she came out of nowhere! Kimmy, you just… appeared, right? Where did you come from?
^Kimmy: Ferry Street... I untied myself from the porch so I could go for a walk…
^Mom: It’s ok dear, let’s go to your house Kimmy… you said it’s on Ferry Street? Your parents are probably worried.

Intro: ^Kimmy's house sits next to the Ferry Corner Store, which is currently closed.
^Kimmy's Mother is standing patiently on her porch.

g-0: ^Dana: I’m sorry… I thought God sent me a baby and I got so excited…
^Kimmy's Mom: Oh, don’t worry. Thank you for finding Kimmy and walking her home. What's your name, dear?
^Kimmy's Mom: I don’t know many kids as responsible as you, walking Kimmy all the way home. I hope you two can be friends. I know Kimmy could learn a lot from you.
g-1: ^Dana: Yes! I’d love to be friends, Kimmy. Can I come by and play with you tomorrow?
^Kimmy's Mom: I’ve been looking for a babysitter, actually. Her grandma was helping with that before, but she… well, she can’t anymore.
g-2: ^Kimmy's Mom: Kimmy’s normally alright in her harness on the porch, but she’s getting a little old for that…
g-3: ^Kimmy's Mom: If you’d like to play with Kimmy tomorrow, I’d be happy to pay you a quarter to keep an eye on her.
^Dana: Wow! Yes, please! I’d love to!
^Kimmy's Mom: My work schedule is a little… hectic. It’d be great to have you by in the morning.
^Dana: I’ll be here first thing! Wow, I didn’t expect to land a job today. Thanks so much!
^Mom: Well, that all sounds good to me. A summer job will be a nice way to keep busy. Now then, let’s leave this nice family to their dinner.
g-4: ^Dana: Ok. Bye bye Kimmy, and Mrs...?
^Kimmy's Mom: Mrs. Munro. Again, thank you for giving Kimmy a hand. It was nice meeting you, Mrs. Navarro.

Day1Intro: ^The next morning, you find Kimmy at her house for your first day of babysitting.

g-0: ^Dana: Mornin’ Kimmy! I’m here to babysit, like I promised! Is your mom around?
^Kimmy: My mommy’s not inside. She left already.
^Dana: Oh, ok… Um, well… Is there anything you’d like to do today, Kimmy?
g-1: ^Dana: That’s ok, do you have a friend you’d like to visit?
g-2: ^Dana: Should we watch TV or something in your house?
^Kimmy: We don’t have a TV. My dad is in there too, so we should go play somewhere else. He’s busy.
^Dana: Ok then! Want to walk around and play some games with the other kids?
^Dana: You know, the neighborhood kids. Like Donna. Isn’t she your age? You’re both going to be in Kindergarten, right?
g-3: ^Kimmy: Oh, yeah… I don’t think Donna is my friend though, so she probably wouldn’t want to play...
^Dana: Well, let’s go become her friend! There's lots of other kids around, too. Like Anthony. I know him from school.

Day1: ^The Ferry Corner Store is open. Dean stands at the counter, waiting to help the next customer.
^Donna stands on the sidewalk. She is wearing mouse ears.

Intro: ^Dana: Hi, Dean. This is Kimmy. I’m babysitting her now.
^Dean: Well lookit that, aren’t you all grown up. You gettin’ paid?

g-0: ^Kimmy: My mom pays Dana a quarter a day.
^Dana: That’s right! I’m here to buy some things… I mean, I haven’t gotten paid yet. This is my first day. But I have some money saved up!
^Dean: Hah, I wish I had that kinda discipline. I blew my budget on fabric last week.
g-1: ^Dana: I need to save up money. For college, you know! My mom would get so mad if I didn’t plan ahead.
^Dean: Hah! Your mom’s got the right idea. I wish I’d saved up for college.
^Dana: So what did you spend all your money on? Your sewing classes?
^Dean: Nah, that’s over. I’m workin’ on some Halloween costumes for my cousins… and some new pants for myself. You know, gotta apply those skills somehow.
g-2: ^Kimmy: I didn’t know people made clothes!
^Dean: They do, Kimmy, they do. I make sweaters, dresses, hats--you name it.
^Dana: You should sell your clothes at Jordan Marsh! That’s where I always find the nicest clothes.
^Dean: Hah! That’s a long ways off for me. But maybe someday… anyways, what can I get for ya?

Intro: ^Donna: What happened, Kimmy? Did you untie yourself from the porch again?
KimmySilent: ^It seems that Kimmy has something to say.

g-0: ^Dana: Hi Donna! I’m babysitting Kimmy now, so--
^Donna: So you untied Kimmy from the porch? Better not let her parents catch you.
g-1: ^Dana: First of all, I’m her babysitter. Second, she’s perfectly able to untie herself. She’s too old for that thing now, even her mom thinks so.
^Donna: She should probably stay on her porch. We’re the same age, but my mom takes me everywhere so I won’t get lost. I bet Kimmy would get lost if she wandered too far.
g-2: ^Dana: I don’t know about that. Anyways, I was just going to ask if you wanna play with us... but I feel like you're being mean to Kimmy.
^Donna: Oh, no. I'm just being honest!
^Dana: Ok... well, I hope you two can get along, since you're neighbors... want to play a game with us?
^Donna: Well, I’m trying to avoid Harold so it’s probably good to look busy. He keeps trying to tell me that my ears look childish. He is so snobby.
g-3: ^Donna: Oh, thanks. They’re new. Anyways, I wanna play a new game.

PickGame: ^What would you like to play with?

c-0: ^ Ok, I'll teach you how to play Yahtzee.
^ Ok, I'll teach you how to play catch.
^ Ok, I'll teach you how to play jacks.
^ Ok, I'll teach you how to play hopscotch.
^ Ok, I'll teach you how to play tic-tac-toe.
^ Ok, I'll teach you how to play tug-of-war.

NoGames: ^Dana: Oh no! I’m sorry… I thought I had some stuff to play games with in my bag… but it looks like I ran out.
^Dana: It’s ok! Kimmy, let’s run to the store and buy some game pieces! We’ll be right back!

g-0: ^Donna: I’m surprised, normally you’re so quiet Kimmy.
g-1: ^Kimmy: Mom said it’s ok to be quiet.
^Dana: That’s right! Games are a nice way to talk and play with your friends though, don’t you think? Even quiet kids like games, I think, usually.
g-2: ^Kimmy: … Are we friends? I thought you were my babysitter.
^Dana: Yes! Of course we’re friends! I know we just met yesterday, but… that’s normal!
^Kimmy: I always thought babysitters were more like parents.
^Dana: I can be your friend AND your babysitter. We’re having fun playing games together, right? That’s what friends do a lot of the time.
g-3: ^Dana: Anthony and I became friends by playing games together. We met playing kickball.
^Donna: Anthony and his little sister Amber are… annoying. Don’t tell them I said that though…
^Dana: Really? Anthony and I go to the same school and do sports together sometimes. He’s way nicer than the other boys at my school. I like him and Amber.
g-4: ^Donna: There’s no rule that says you have to like your classmates.
^Dana: Yeah, I know… but Anthony is nice to me, so I like him.
g-5: ^Dana: …I’m not going to answer that, Donna. Who I like is none of your business.

FriendSuccess: ^Donna: ...Are you gonna walk to Jordan Marsh? That’s where my babysitter used to take me.
^Dana: Maybe! Kimmy doesn't seem to know too many people around town though, so I think we should save big trips for later.
^Donna: Playing is fine, but isn’t it boring sometimes? I need more friends  who will go with me to Jordan Marsh. I like going shopping there. I hide in the clothes racks sometimes.

g-0: ^Kimmy: Dad took me there once. He needed a new leather jacket. But then he bought another new guitar and mom got mad when we came home.
^Dana: Haha, your dad is so weird.
^Donna: I don’t see your dad around much anymore, but I guess that’s because I’m not out on the porch like I used to be.
^Kimmy: Donna used to be in a harness outside, like me.
g-1: ^Donna: Yeah I used to wear a harness attached to the front door when my mom was cooking or doing laundry. It was so embarrassing.
^Donna: My mom said I’m too big for the harness. I go bike riding a lot now. I went by myself to Jordan Marsh yesterday and got these ears…
^Dana: I like riding my bike to Jordan Marsh too! Sometimes I’ll buy a ribbon if I save up.
g-2: ^Dana: Wow! Really? I can get you one, Kimmy, don’t worry.
^Kimmy: No thank you, I’m not supposed to spend any money. I don’t have any anyways.
^Dana: I’ll save up and get you one!
^Donna: Kimmy, you would look nice in a ribbon. Cat ears too probably.

global decl: ^Then, you have lots of ways to roll dice, but only some are quiet.
^Then, you have 5 ways to toss the dice at your friend.
^Then, you have 13 combinations of dice that you want to roll.
^Now, you get points if you roll the dice and they don't make a sound.
^Now, you take turns rolling the dice. Add them up to get points from certain combinations.
^Now, you get points if you catch the dice when your friend tries to roll them.
^You win if you rolled the quietest dice!
^You win if you scored the most points!
^You win if you caught the most dice!
^You need a frisbee and a bag of candies.
^You need a frisbee and a soda.
^You need a frisbee and a sidewalk.
^Then, your friends stand and you sit in the middle with the soda.
^Then, you have two friends stand on opposite sides, and you stand in the middle.
^Then, everyone passes the frisbee around. One piece of candy also gets passed around.
^Now, your friends toss the frisbee. If you don't catch it, swap out with the last kid to toss.
^Now, your friends try to knock the soda out of your hands with the ball.
^Now, if a candy is tossed to you, you have to catch it in your mouth.
^You win if you catch the frisbee 10 times.
^You win if you drink the most soda.
^You win if you eat the most candies.
^You need a bouncy ball and a box of Jacks.
^You need a bouncy ball and bubbles.
^You need a bouncy ball and chicken eggs.
^Then, you bounce the ball and pick up one of the Jacks before it bounces twice.
^Then, you line up all the Jacks in a row.
^Then, you arrange the Jacks into a little sculpture.
^Now, let your friends try to knock over your Jacks sculpture using the ball.
^Now, roll an egg at the Jacks.
^Now, try to pick up one extra Jack every time you take a turn.
^You win if you're the first to pick up all five Jacks in a single turn.
^You win if your friends decide that your sculpture was the nicest.
^You win if you knock the most Jacks out of line using your egg.
^Then, count how many snacks you have and draw that many squares in a column using your chalk.
^Then, put the eggs on the ground and draw small squares around them.
^Then, use your chalk to draw ten squares all in a column, with some rows containing two squares.
^Now, everyone hops through the squares all at once, trying to pick up snacks.
^Now, toss the rock into a square and hop to the other end of the column, picking it up on your way back.
^Now, each player takes turns hopping through the egg squares, trying not to squash them.
^You win if you finish ten turns without breaking more than one egg.
^You win if you pick up your rock without falling or tossing it outside of the column ten times.
^You win if you pick up the most snacks.
^Then, you draw X's, and the other draws O's.
^Then, you draw cookies and the other draws cakes.
^Now, your friend guesses who your crush is.
^Now, draw all your cookies and cakes as fast as you can for ten seconds.
^Now, take turns drawing your X's and O's.
^You win if you guess your friends crush.
^You win if you drew more cookies or cakes within ten seconds.
^You win if you get three of your symbols in a row.
^You need a rope and a ribbon.
^You need a rope and a staircase.
^Then, tie a ribbon around the middle of the rope, and mark the ground with two parallel goal lines.
^Then, you each hold one end of the rope on a different side of the puddle.
^Then, you each hold one end of the rope, one at the top of the stairs and one at the bottom.
^Now, you each hold one end of the rope, and tug as hard as you can.
^Now, you try to pull each other into the puddle using the rope.
^Now, the friend at the bottom of the stairs ties the rope around their waist.
^You win if you can pull your friend into the puddle.
^You win if you can pull the rope's ribbon across your side, where the marking closest to you.
^You win if you can pull the other friend to the top of the stairs using the rope.
